On the moving dots towards the end, I think there are 2 illusions coinciding to create the connecting lines.

First, when the circles move over the box, it causes the sides of the box to appear as if they bend towards it, similar to how shadows and other shapes will appear to bend towards one another as they connect or overlap.

Second, is the contrast effect of when an object is suddenly removed (most notable with solid colors) we will often see a negative of the vanished object.

So as the circles overlap the rectangle it causes the sides of the rectangle to appear to bend outward to meet the circle. This creates a series of lines that are angled vaguely towards the dots. Additionally, since the sides of the box are lighter than the circles the "negative" we see when its covered by the circle will be a darker line, reinforcing the bent segments as well as extending them into the circle (ie as it moves you see a small bit of white line bent towards the dots just outside the circle as well as a small bit of dark line that was just covered up by the circle).

This is why the contour line is much more apparent when the circles are moving inward, but are almost absent when the circles move back out (we still get a little bit of the uncovered box appearing to be bent, but no darker negative enhancing the effect).

Then because these small bent lines appear to move in a similar manner as the dots, and the lines are bent vaguely towards the dots, our brain assumes that their motion is connected and finishes the line in our mind.

Hey Science. There is this thing called depth, and when we perceive depth it is always a fixed observation. The consistency of the darkness inside the white box allows just that, a constant. With the combined movement of the white dots and grey circles (the circles seeming to trail the dots), our brain senses an uncomfortable feeling similar to vertigo, but on a much smaller scale. This is why the box may seem to approach you, or entirely different, you may see a dark circle enlarging from the center.

The reason the bulgy thing in that illusion at the end does that is because our minds probably view white as the 'color' of light. When the dark grey circles cover it, our minds associate it as something that could cause a shadow, and of course, creates the weird bulging effect. I think...

There's not a mechanism, but there's this cool thing our brain does called 'logical thinking'. The brain is used to seeing dots connected, so when they move apart they seem to be connected. Remove the box or slow down the animation and the invisible line will disappear.

I'm amazed you idiots haven't been able to figure this one out. That white square tricks our eyes into continuing the dot chain. At the points at which the grey circle interrupts the white square, we assume the white of the cut off square are more dots, and our mind lines up the chain of dots. The quick switch between imagined dots and real dots makes this line more visible. Can't believe a 14 year old could figure out that?

@vsauce About the illusion at the end.  When the circles move over the square, the contrast makes the points when the white line meets the gray circle stand out enough to be perceived as 2 intermediary dots between the 4 main dots. This effectively means that the brain sees 12 points of reference instead of 4, and because of that it's a lot easier to recognize and trace a contour than with just 4 points.
